text: Anyway... Her chipper Brooklyn/Jersey accent rings out:
Marnie makes her way through the store, happy and confuse
Today I went across the street to the Apple store and got one of the new iPhones with the 64 gigabytes cause I wasn't sure if I should get the 16s or the 64s but the 64s looked good so there you go.
Marnie has breakfast with her iPhone.

The genius bartender showed me how to make things bigger but I already forgot. God, my eyesight is so shot. But I got on the Safari before and I looked up The Palazzo and it said they filmed “The Hills" here for two seasons. Isn't that neat? -- Marnie happily weaves through The Grove’s morning crow
And they used to do the Extra program at The Grove every day with Mario Lopez. He seems nice. -- Marnie stands shyly at the fountain, watching the chi play nearby.

I swear I could stand there and watch that fountain for hours. Today they played “Come Fly With Me" and I almost started crying thinking about Daddy. But I didn't cause basically, I feel great. -- Marnie buys a Wetzel Pretzel.

It's like living on Main Street in Disneyland. Every day is sunny and I wake up and I think, “Thank you, Joey, for making it possible.” -- The trolley man rings the bell, Marnie scuttles out of way, packages from Crate & Barrel in her arms.
I swear, if I get hit by that trolley, I'll die happy.
Marnie puts pillows, still tagged, on her small couch.
And just wait ‘til you see my apartment. -- Marnie has a cup of decaf at the kitchen table.
I have a balcony that's far enough from other peoples' balconies so nobody could jump down from the roof or whatever... -- Marnie looks off her small balcony, eyeing, suspicious
And I have a parking spot right next to the elevator so I can just run right in there. -- Underground, Marnie sprints from her Toyota toward the elevator, bags in hand.
And I got everything shipped out from Jersey. All my artwork... -- Marnie hangs up a local-artist painting of Kermit the playing guitar in the woods.
The doll I had made of you... -- Marnie sets out a HANDMADE DOLL replicated to look lik her DAUGHTER as a little kid, next to a matching photo.
And of course the pictures of me and Daddy on our honeymoon. -- She slides a photo in her mirror. A YOUNGER MARNIE and her HANDSOME ITALIAN HUSBAND when he was alive.

God, I can't believe I smoked back then. I hope you're not still smoking. It's really bad for you. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- MORNING 5 Marnie awkwardly drives up Laurel Canyon, holding her iPh on speaker.
Anyway... call me back. Love you. She hangs up. Then turns up her Beyonce CD, humming along

INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- SAME TIME 6 LORI (30s) lies face down in bed, a cell phone buzzing in outstretched hand. She looks at it. CLOSE on: MA VOICEMAIL (5) Lori closes her eyes again. Almost immediately, the doorb RINGS. She sits up. INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER 7 Lori opens the door to see Marnie holding up a brown bag.
I brought bagels.
You should've called.
I did.
But I didn’t answer.
Well, I’m sure you were busy. Marnie hugs Lori, then gives her the bag. Lori follows he inside the small, neglected house.
Say hi to your grand-dogs. TWO MUTTS jump and sniff at Marnie. She pets them with th back of her hand, clearly uncomfortable.
Hi, doggies. Hello. Marnie shuts the front door, leaving the dogs outside.
(looking in bag) Six bagels. All salt.
They're the best kind. (seeing something) Oh Lor, you let Daddy’s bonsai die? Marnie goes to the bonsai, trying to spruce it back to li
Yeah... Sorry, Mom... I tried. They're like crazy delicate. It was... crazy. Marnie tsks sadly, then whispers to Heaven:
Sorry, Joey.
See, this is why I asked you not to put me in charge. (MORE )
You can’t just give someone a man’s bonsai and orchid and put all this pressure on them.
You let the orchid die too?
Yes “I let it die”. I watered it every day.
Oh, Lor, you’re not supposed to water it every day.
Well, I watered it the right amount, okay? Plants die. It’sa part of plant life. Please don’t make me feel any more bad about it.
Alright, forget it. Lori puts a bagel in the toaster. Marnie looks through a pile of Lori’s mail and sees an INVITATION.
What’s this?
Emily's baby shower.
Do you get to bring somebody?
Why? I probably won’t go.
Why not?
Cause I’1ll have to get all dressed up... And it’s gonna be like everyone I know there... Lori disappears into a cabinet.
I thought you stopped smoking.
(holding in smoke) Cigarettes. (exhaling) You said this was better.
I said it was okay after your father died when your stomach hurt.
Well, it’s after my father died. And my stomach hurts. Lori disappears into the cabinet again.
Well, have you heard from Jacob? You shouldn’t call him. What’s going on with work? Did they call you about the pilot? You shouldn't be smoking if you have a deadline.
Mom. Please. Don’t say deadline. Don’t say pilot. And do not, please, ever again, say the word Jacob, okay?
Alright. (then) I just don’t think you should call him. Especially when you have a deadline on your pilot. Jacob, I mean. Lori bites her cheek.
We should find you a hobby. (then) I thought you were gonna volunteer at the hospital.
Yeah, I keep meaning to do that. (then) Or maybe you could be my hobby. Lori looks up, eyes wide. A bagel POPS out of the toaster Mother and daughter both jump.  10
Marnie steps up to the ticket counter.
Three for “Fight School”.
Marnie sits alone, eating popcorn in the back row of a Li Neeson movie. She enjoys the explosive action.
Marnie is being helped by FREDDY (20s, GENIUS T-shirt).
And you just put your fingers on the screen like this...
Oh, look at that, you magnified it. (squinting) So if I wanted to look up an address for a baby shower?
Well, you’d go on Safari and...
Oh you just Google it?
Yeah you just type it in. And if you need to find it again, it’s in your search history. There.
Oh my god Freddy, you really are a genius.
(humble) It’s just a label.
Your mother must be so proud.
I guess so.  11
Well, I would be. My daughter’s a genius, but she’s too old for you. How old are you?
I turn twenty-three in October.
Get outta here. Happy Birthday. What does that make you? A Libra? What does that mean? It’s the scales, right? Justice? You're probably very diplomatic. You should be a lawyer.
Maybe.
You should. Marnie smiles. Freddy nods, not sure how to respond.
Marnie, wearing black as usual, tries to mingle with vari 30-SOMETHING WOMEN at a fancy BABY SHOWER. -- Marnie stands on the outskirts of one group.

You should get the kind I have. Transitions. They go from regular glasses to sunglasses when you walk outside. You can find ‘em anywhere... Lenscrafters.... (pulling out her iPhone) You want me to make you an appointment? -- Marnie interrupts an ENGAGED WOI --
You’re gonna want to clean that with Windex. -- To an INFERTILE WOMAN --
What you should do is have him tip you upside-down. That’s what Joe and I did when we conceived Lori.  12
And this one’s from Mrs. Minervini. Marnie sits among the much-younger group, feeling under- dressed, awkwardly squeezed next to a tree. They watch EM (30s, pregnant) unwrap a white box.
Oh my god... an iPad. The women “ooh” and “ah” at it, a bit confused.
Wow, Marnie, that’s crazy generous.
Well, I know it wasn’t on your list but I went to the Apple store the other day and I saw this little Filipino boy, practically a baby, playing on one of these, what do you call it’s...
... iPads...
... iPads... And then Freddy told me they have all these programs you can download, like Barney’s Circus and Nemo--
Thanks, Marnie. That’s sooo0o nice. Lori has the best mom ever. Emily moves on to other gifts. Marnie goes back to eating scone. The BRUNETTE (30s) sitting next to her, leans in.
Where is Lori?
Oh, I think she’s working today. She's got that deadline. I mean... countdown.
She said she’d baby-sit Tehya tonight. Dani and I haven’t gotten out in a year.  13 10.
Oh, well I could-- A BLONDE WOMAN (30s) leans in.
I thought she was out of town. A CURLY-HAIRED WOMAN (30s) leans in, holding a TINY DOG.
She told me she was sick.
Oh. Well, she was sick....
I'd be sick too. With everything Jacob puts her through.
She’s so pretty. Why can’t she just get over him?
She's never gonna get over him if she keeps giving him what he wants. They all nod in agreement. Marnie looks at them.
What does he want?
OMG shut it. Everyone turns back to Emily holding up a tiny onesie.
Does this come in my size? I’m kidding. I know it doesn’t. The women ooh and ah at it, except Marnie.
What does he want?
Marnie is standing by the buffet table, a pastry in one h her iPhone in the other. She texts Lori: Where r u?
Marnie? 11. Marnie turns to see the mom-to-be with an OLDER MAN (60s)
Marnie, this is Greg’s dad. He came out to help us with the nursery.
Mark, hi.
Oh. Marnie. She gestures with her hands full.
He’s in town til Thursday. Emily walks away. It takes awhile for Marnie to finish he bite. Finally:
So you're out visiting your son?
Yeah. Emily said it was important that I come but... I think I’m just here to carry gifts. (laughs, then) His mother isn’t around.
Oh, my husband died a year ago.
Oh. Well, she lives in London, but, we're divorced.... Marnie takes a sip of her drink.
Emily said that you grew up in Brooklyn. Which, um, which part?
Near Sunset Park.
I lived on the corner of 48th and 7th right by the church.  12.
Get outta here. I was on 43rd and 4th right by the other church.
We used to go to the public pool before it became a parking lot.
Get outta here. I went there every summer we weren't with my aunt at Greenwood Lake.
I bet we ran in similar circles.
Isn’t that funny? She laughs.
Well, maybe before I leave town, we can have lunch with the girls. Marnie stops, frozen, unable to breathe.
Or there's this Holocaust museum I’ve been meaning to check out. Have you been to the Holocaust museum? Marnie finally exhales, flustered, and starts piling food her plate.

Oh, yeah, no, I can’t, I’ve got so much to do, settling into my apartment, getting all my papers in order, plus I’m just about to start volunteering at the hospital... And maybe get into baby-sitting, so... She backs away from him.
(too loud) I’ve never been so busy. She puts down the full plate and scuttles away.
14 15 16 17 18 13. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- DAY 14 Marnie drives while leaving Lori a voicemail, on speaker.

Anyway... I just wanted to tell you that I’m on my way to the hospital to volunteer. So give me a call soon or else I’1ll already be in there and it’ll be too hard to reach me, okay? Oh and I’ve been listening to the best Beyonce song! She turns up the volume, the same Beyonce song we’ve alre heard in progress. Marnie holds up the phone for a verse. Then lowers it:

Anyway, I’m almost at the hospital so give me a call. Soon. Otherwise I’1ll already be in there. Okay. Love you. Marnie hangs up, then turns up the song. When it comes to end, she starts it over again. It continues:
Through the double doors, Marnie is frozen, hesitating to come inside. SOMEONE is wheeled outside, opening the door automatically. Marnie finally walks through.

Marnie sits among the sick and injured, filling out a volunteer form. She writes in her name and address. She puts down Lori as her emergency contact. She stops at marital status, unsure what to write. A HOMELESS WOMAN (40s) coughs loudly across from her. Mar looks up and gives a polite smile.
The demons are chasing me. With their dicks.  19 14.
Oh. Well, that must be scary.
It is. Can you buy me a Sprite?

Sure. Marnie puts down her volunteer form. And makes her way toward the VENDING MACHINES. She weaves in between patien and their ailments. Someone coughs. Someone cries. Marnie puts a dollar in the machine, pushes the button, n hearing the TELEVISION playing the NEWS above her.
... Within ten miles of where the skeletal remains were found. Police suspect this could be the work of a serial killer that's been targeting young women in the area since 2005...
Can I get my Sprite? Marnie jumps, startled, as the homeless woman takes the s and disappears. Marnie looks around at all the people in need and starts backing away from them all, panicked.
Excuse me, Sorry.... She quickly bursts out of the hospital doors. INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- MORNING 19 Marnie unlocks the door with a key, holding a brown bag.
Lori? There’s no answer. Marnie greets the dogs, then rounds th corner, into the bedroom --
Don’t you get the mail anymore? Lori screams from inside the shower. Then pokes around th shower curtain.  15.
Jesus, Mom, I was shaving. You need to ring the fucking doorbell.
But I have the key.
Well, what if I had company?
Who? Jacob?
No. Who told you that? Marnie looks at the TV. A TEEN SOAP plays, MUTED. ON TV: HANDSOME ACTOR (30s) charms a PRETTY ACTRESS (20s).
Your friends at the baby shower. Lori disappears behind the curtain again.
Please don’t talk to my friends, okay? They’re not my friends. And you’re not supposed to plus one when there isn’t a one to plus.
Well, you never told me if you were going or not. Did you get my message about the serial killer? He’s been all over Southern California, targeting young women.
Well, we should be fine then.
Maybe we should have a system in place, like if you let me know every time you’re leaving the house and then text me when you get home.
That’s crazy.
Just until the guy is caught. And if you ever run into him, remember “Eyes, Throat, Crotch.”  16.
Mom, maybe you shouldn’t just drop by here all the time.

But I barely see you. Marnie looks at Lori’s computer and does a quick scan of Lori’s SEARCH HISTORY. In reverse order: Jacob Mailer girlfriend 2015 > Jacob Mailer girlfriend > Jacob Mailer > weird color stool > green stool > least painful suicide > how much valium does it take to kill yourself > adoption agencies LA > adoption

I just have a ton of work to do. And it requires a lot of research. Lori shuts off the faucet. Marnie quickly moves away from the computer and sits on the bed as Lori wraps herself in robe and steps out. They look at each other.
I’m just saying, I’m in no shape to be entertaining right now. I don’t have any good stories.
Is there anything you want to talk about? Lori rushes into the living room. Marnie follows.

Didn't you hear what I just said? What I need to do is write, okay? This is my office. This is my desk. (gesturing to couch) These are my coworkers. (gesturing to dogs) If I was in a real office, you wouldn’t just come in and sit on my desk and pet my coworkers, would you? Marnie tries to answer correctly.
No? Lori takes a breath.  17.
I've been talking to my therapist about it and I think we need to establish... certain... boundaries. Marnie tries to hide how much this hurts.
Sure. I get it. You need to work. I‘1l get out of your office. Marnie starts out. Lori feels guilty immediately.
You don’t have to leave right now.

No, it’s fine. Wouldn't want to cross peoples’ boundaries. 20 INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE -- LATER 20 Marnie sits across from DIANE (40s) perched in a papasan chair. Next to her, a desk and a RABBIT in a cage.

And I just think she’s never gonna get over him if she keeps giving him what he wants. You know? And I think she’d feel better if she at least, you know, tried to get over him, but she just seems so angry all the time... I mean, you’ve been seeing her for awhile, did she always seem so angry? (no response) I just don’t want her to hurt herself or anything, I mean, has she talked to you about that? I’m not saying I want to know anything, I just hope that if she’s talking to you, she’s talking to you about the right stuff and that, you know, you tell her not to hurt herself or anything. And that she should quit smoking grass. I mean, I know she’s in some stage of grief or something....
And what about you?  21 18.
What about me?
How do you feel?
Well, I feel like she should find other ways to make herself feel better besides marijuana.
I mean, how do you feel since your husband died?

Oh. Well, of course I get sad. But I don’t think I’m as stressed as Lori is cause I don’t have to worry about a career or money. I mean, Joey left me set for life, so really I can do anything. Like when I go to an action movie, I always buy three tickets. One for me, one for Joe and one for my mother, and I don’t have to worry about it. I mean, I spend a lot of time by myself and sometimes I don’t really know what to do with the hours in the day so I call Lori, but it’s not like she really wants my advice or like I have anything important to say... (adrift, then) But basically I feel fine. I love my apartment. And of course you can't beat this weather. I mean, who doesn’t love The Grove? It’s like living on Main Street in Disneyland. Marnie smiles. Diane reaches for her notepad.

-- Marnie unlocks the front door and locks it behind her. -- Marnie spruces the dead bonsai out on the balcony, try to bring it back to life. -- Marnie does a Sudoku puzzle on her phone. -- Marnie leaves another message after the beep.  19.

Anyway, let me know that you got in safe. Oh and remind me to tell you what your therapist said. -- Marnie makes a single cup of decaf, while watching TV; more about the serial killer called “Red Ripper”. Marnie tsks at the gruesome crime photos. -- Marnie takes forever to send Lori a text “Cl me”. The history of texts is very one-sided. -- Marnie falls asleep in bed next to her iPhone playing sounds of the ocean. The ceiling fan spins above Marnie.
Marnie and Lori sit across from each other, both dressed black, surrounded by Valentine’s Day decorations.
It’s so good to see you out of the house. And for such a nice occasion. Lori reaches for her drink. Marnie reaches for the bread.
Mmmmm... Pretzel bread reminds me of my father. Well... pretzels. (then, to Heaven) And I got risotto for Daddy. Lori downs her drink. Marnie munches.
If Daddy saw me eating like this, you know what he’d say... (bad Italian accent) “Marnie, you're killing yourself.”
(trying to be funny) Well, you got the last laugh. Marnie smiles, but doesn’t laugh. Lori clears her throat.
So... listen, I have to go to New York for a few weeks. To shoot the pilot.  20.
New York? Why?

Well, cause the show is set there, so it’s actually a good thing. But I wanted to tell you that I’m not gonna be reachable, like, at all, for a few weeks. Like someone else will be holding my phone for me. But I was thinking at the end of it, maybe you could come visit the set and we can finally think about getting a headstone for Dad. Or at least maybe figure out what to do with his ashes....
Sure, we can talk about all that before you go. There’s no rush.
Well, I leave tomorrow.
Tomorrow? (sinking in) That’s really soon.
I know. But if you want to come over after dinner and help me pack and maybe even crash so you could take me to the airport in the morning, that’d be fun....
Well, of course, but are you sure you don’t want me to come with you? I could be like your assistant.
(quick) No. No, if anything I’d need you here. Watching the house and taking care of your grand-dogs. Marnie sighs.
It’s my job, Mom.  21.
No, of course. You're right. That’s great news.
It is. And it’s really good timing for me, you know? I can get out of town and be busy and finally take my mind off things. Marnie suddenly gasps.
Jacob.

Exactly-- Then Lori follows Marnie’s wide eyes to see JACOB (30s), handsome actor we recognize from TV. He comes toward them holding hands with a VERY TALL GIRL (20s). SOMEONE stops him/them for a picture. They finally reach the table.
Hey, you two.
Hey. You two.
Hey, Marnie.
Jacob, good to see you. I never had anything bad to say about you. Marnie looks down, trying not to say things.
(to Lori) You know Elise.
Hi.
Yeah. They stand there awkwardly for a second.
Well, we don’t want to interrupt your girl time.  23 22.
Oh no it’s fine. We’re just doing a drive-by before I head out later. I just didn’t want her to have to spend Valentine’s Day alone.
And I didn’t want her to be alone.
I’m not alone.
That's right. We're here together.
Until later. And then I’m with other people.
I thought I was sleeping over.
Aw, that’s so cute. I wish my mom and I were that close.
Oh, well, maybe when you get older. INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- NIGHT 23 Lori charges in and slams the door behind her. The door t opens and Marnie walks inside, shutting it again.
What would make you happy? Lori flops onto the couch.
If I could be stuffed into a cannon and shot into space.
Should we go get milkshakes? Lori screams into a pillow.
Why don’t we go to a waterpark this week?  23.
I’m going to kill myself.
Don’t say that.
I can’t live here anymore, Mom. There’s no safe place. My TV is haunted. My job is make believe. And just when I wanted to hit the eject button, you move here.
What does that mean?
It means, I tried to book a session with my therapist to talk about my mother, and I couldn’t. Because my mother was there.
You said maybe I should talk to her after Daddy died. So?

Don’t you understand that eighty percent of the time my phone rings, it’s you? The phone rings, and I think it could be a guy or a friend or a job and it’s my mother. Almost every single time. Do you understand how terrible that makes me feel? Marnie blinks, stung.
Well, I could call you less. Like if I don’t hear back from you, I could just text you. Lori suddenly breaks down, sobbing. Marnie goes to her.
I’m never gonna get over him.
How can I help? What can I do?
Nothing.  24 25 24. Lori pulls out her phone and starts texting.
Who are you texting? Don’t act out.
Mom, I need to have sex with someone else, and you can’t be here for it.
Okay, just not with Jacob. Lori's body explodes, shoving Marnie out of her room.
Please, Mom, I can’t do this anymore. I need to get a life of my own, okay? And so do you. Lori slams the door. Marnie sighs. A sad beat, then Lori talks from the other side of the door.
I still need a ride to the airport. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- MORNING 24 Marnie drives, Lori is quiet in the passenger seat. They make their way up to the terminal.
Do you have everything?

I have no idea. Lori kisses Marnie on the head, then drags out two suitca shutting the door behind her. Marnie watches her daughter until she gets safely inside. Then she slowly pulls away. We stay with Marnie as she drives ahead. The silence is deafening. Marnie quickly turns on Beyonce, humming along She reaches for her phone. About to call Lori. Then.... S puts the phone down. Both hands on the wheel. Determined.
Marnie stands in the hospital hallway staring at a sign. “Volunteer Center” to the left. “Gift Shop” to the right.  26 27 28 29 25.
Marnie strolls though the gift shop, scanning the differe stuffed animals. She decides on a STUFFED BUNNY. Its goof face makes her smile.

Marnie strolls the halls with the stuffed bunny, trying t walk tall. There’s a LOUD BEEPING. Nurses rush through wi an emergency. Marnie starts to look uneasy. Up ahead, a MAN IN A GOWN (60s) dragging his IV. He’s com toward her. As he gets closer and closer to her, she turn away, pushing through a door --

Marnie ducks into the room and shuts the door behind her, noise of the hospital hallway is muffled. She looks up to see an OLD WOMAN (80s), lying in bed, mouth agape, no visitors. Something next to her is beeping. Marnie takes a few small steps up to the hospital bed.
Hi. Hello. She leans over to see some wires twisted under the woman’ twisted arm. Marnie reaches down and fixes the wires, mov her arm into a more comfortable position. The beeping sto
Is anyone here with you? The old woman slowly raises her arm. Her finger extends, pointing. Marnie lowers her arm, placing the stuffed bunn in her hand.
Here. I’11 get someone. Marnie slowly backs away and out of the room.
Marnie quickly finds a NURSE (40s).  30 31 26.

Excuse me, the woman in 142, I don’t know if she’s in pain. Could you just? The nurse walks off toward the woman’s room. Marnie watch feeling proud of herself, a smile curling on her face, as continues down the hall. PRE-LAP: A doorbell.
The brunette from the baby shower, JILLIAN, opens the doo see Marnie.
Marnie? What are you doing here?
You said you needed a baby-sitter. Marnie holds up a brown bag.
I brought bagels.
Jillian cuts up a salt bagel for her daughter, TEHYA (4 y old).

I swear, I’m like the only one of my friends without full-time help. And in this town, it literally cost more than my salary to hire a decent nanny. So I quit. And now I’m home all day. All day, every day. Isn’t that right, Tehya? Tehya screams.
You could go into the nanny business. Jillian looks at Marnie and cracks up, laughing.
Oh my god. That’s like the funniest thing ever said, ever. (MORE )
No wonder Lori’s so funny. Well, not anymore, but.... Marnie reaches out to Tehya, but she runs off to the othe side of the room to eat her bagel.
It’s just nobody ever tells you how lonely it is. Like some days, I don’t think I talk to another grown person the entire day. Like by the time Dani gets home, I can’t even turn off the baby talk.
Well, that’s normal.
Really?
But just think, someday you and Tehya will be having like real conversations... You could talk about everything. Like me and Lori.

Yeah. You're right. I don’t know why I worry so much like I’m not doing it right. Like at any moment I’m gonna do the thing that gives her a body complex or a foot fetish.... I don’t know. I lost my mom when I was young so... I’m kinda flying blind. Jillian lets out a laugh. Marnie stops.
Oh, yeah. Lori said something about that, I’m sorry. (then) Well, anytime you need a baby- sitter, you can call on me. Jillian smiles.
Lori's lucky to have you so close. If she ever has kids. My dad couldn’t even fly in for my fake wedding. I had to walk myself down the aisle.  28.
Aw. Why was your wedding fake?

Because. It was at City Hall and we had just found out that the adoption had gone through and I told myself that I didn’t care about having a special day. I just wanted a quickie wedding and we'd have a real wedding sometime after we got Tehya home. But then I thought it'd be so selfish to spend any of the money I’d spend on her on having a special day, so.... Marnie looks at Tehya who is slamming a toy phone on the opposite side of the room.
What about Danny? Is he working?
She. Marnie tries not to react. If anything, it’s a thrill.
Yeah, Dani’s a chef at Bouchon, but she’s like fifth in line and she works crazy hours.
She does.... The wheels are turning in Marnie’s head.
Well, what if I gave you the money?
What? Marnie turns back to her.

Well, I can gift a certain amount of money to a person per year without having to pay taxes. I mean, I don’t know if it’s enough to make the wedding of your dreams but... thirteen thousand dollars?  29.
Marnie, that’s crazy.
What’s crazy? I have it. You need it. Can't have it sitting there.
You should save it. Spend it on yourself. I mean, wouldn’t Lori be upset?
Why? She’s not getting married.
I just... I mean, why would you want to do that?
Cause. It sounds romantic. Like renewing your vows. Joe and I talked about that. I mean, who doesn’t love love? Jillian bursts into tears and leaps into Marnie’s arms.
Oh my God, this is so totally amazing. Of course you’re gonna be in on all the planning.
Well, only as much as you’d want... What do you think you’1l want?
Oh I don’t know, nothing extravagant.... Dani was in the Navy, so... maybe it could be a nautical theme?

Yes. You could wear a sailor dress and she could wear her uniform. Like Officer and a Gentleman. (she gasps) You could do it on a submarine. CLOSE on Marnie’s face. More excited than the “bride-to-b  32 30.
Freddy helps Marnie look up things on an iPad.
I don’t see any submarines for rent. But there are a bunch of boats at the yacht club in Marina Del Rey.
